id 1.tip 1: Keep this plan updated, and remember you can always reach out if things escalate.

id 1.tip 2: Start packing small items now so you’re ready when you decide to leave.

id 1.tip 3: It's normal to feel unsettled, refer back to this plan whenever you need a safety reminder.

q 2.question: What city do you live in?

id 2.tip: Save the local support numbers for {city} in your phone’s speed-dial so you can call immediately if you need help.

q 3.question: Which room in your home feels the safest if you need to get away quickly?

id 3.tip: Keep your essentials (phone, keys, and a small flashlight) in {safe_room} so you can grab them instantly when you need to leave.

id 4.tip 1: Let those you live with: {family/roommates} know your safe room and cue‐word so they can support you in an emergency.

id 4.tip 2: Since you live alone, identify a trusted neighbor or friend and share your safe room location with them.

id 4.tip 3: Because you live with your partner, keep your safety plan hidden (in {safe_room}), and consider storing a digital copy in a password-protected note they won’t see.

id 5.tip 1: Practice your safety plan with your children so that when they hear {code_word}, they know exactly what to do.

id 5.tip 2: Even without children, it helps to identify a second safe space in your home.

q 6.question: What is your family's safety code word?

q 7.question: Which form(s) of abuse are you experiencing?

id 7.tip: If you face {abuse_type} abuse, remember you don’t have to face it alone. Reach out to your emergency contact right away.

q 8.question: Are you recording the incidents (dates, times, details)?

id 8.tip 1: Log each incident (date, time, and a brief note) so you have clear records if needed later.

id 8.tip 2: Even brief notes on your phone can be helpful. Start logging today.

q 9.question: Name one person you can call immediately in an emergency.

id 9.tip: Save {contact_name} in your phone under a code-word so you can quietly call them when you need help.

q 10.question: When do you plan to leave?

id 10.tip: Set a real target {leave_timing} and pack one essential item each day until you’re ready.

q 11.question: Do you have a go-bag packed with essentials?

id 11.tip 1: Great! Keep your go-bag in a hidden spot so you can grab it quickly.

id 11.tip 2: Pack a simple go-bag today with essentials like your ID, some cash, and a charger.

q 12.question: Where do you keep emergency cash or cards?

id 12.tip: Stash some cash and a spare card in {money_location}, a spot your partner won’t suspect.

q 13.question: Have you identified a safe place to stay?

id 13.tip 1: Make sure {temp_shelter} knows you may arrive unexpectedly and how to contact you.

id 13.tip 2: Reach out to Victim Services Toronto or a trusted friend now to secure a shelter option before you leave.

q 14.question: Where do you plan to stay?

q 15.question: Has the abuser continued any contact?

id 15.tip 1: Since you’ve heard from them, stay vigilant and keep your protection order handy if you have one.

id 15.tip 2: Even without contact, keep your doors locked and your phone on in case you need to call 911.

q 16.question: Do you have a protection order? If yes, which type?

id 16.tip 1: Carry your {legal_order} at all times and share copies with anyone who needs to know.

id 16.tip 2: Consider applying for a protection order; it can help deter unwanted contact.

q 17.question: What legal order do you have?

q 18.question: Are you using any safety tools (cameras, door alarms)?

id 18.tip 1: Make sure your {equipment} is in working order and placed where you’ll notice it.

id 18.tip 2: Consider installing a simple door alarm or camera to alert you to unexpected entry.

q 19.question: What safety tools are you using?

q 20.question: Which type of support would help most right now?

id 20.tip: Reach out to {support_choice} - they can offer the specialized help you need right now.
